title: Will Faraday Future, NextEV, or Atieva start taking orders for electric vehicles in 2016?
preds: No working prototype in sight yet.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
(no change) Just a trip down memory lane regarding what an "order" might entail: http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/245097
Back up 25% based on @Dsarin information that the embedded link in the question takes one to the Lucid order ;-) site: http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/402684

based on the post by @Raisinville,  http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/402052, which I consider brilliantly argued and one that deserves to be retained as a terrific example of excellent logic and organization of ideas.   My forecast would be 100%  but, sad to say, I'm not confident in the good judgment of GJO Admins.

Down 25% on this thought. Unless GJO or Mack made a clarification, why would Lucid taking orders be a yes since the question lists three other entities? (Yes, now Atieva is Lucid, but the paper trail might be complicated and a narrow reading of the question might require a tortured explanation to get there.)
There are no actual cars yet. Their factory in Arizona is not built yet. They expect to bring the car to market in 2018. But Lucid Motors is taking orders. Thanks Raisinville!
I think that this question should resolve as "Yes" retroactively to a day or two ago based on  Raisinville's information.  http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/401337
Up the other 5%. Why not follow @Raisinville OTOH it should probably be back-dated to yesterday or earlier.
Up 95% on @chrislim note below. Should have spent 30 seconds googling instead of scanning a dead tree article. https://cleantechnica.com/2016/11/30/lucid-motors-atieva-factory-400-mile-atvus-arizona/

(no change) Lucid is taking orders, but see no reason to anticipate the three other named companies to immediately follow suit. As been noted before however, the bar for an order (and press coverage) is very low.

Going down, because I had a response from GJO. They say they're not going to resolve this IFP on the NextEV hypercar at this time due to "insufficient evidence that [NextEV] started taking orders during the question's open period." If they find evidence that NextEV began taking orders during the question period, they may resolve the question retroactively. My thinking is that, if the NextEV hypercar is not going to count, who else would be taking orders before the end of the year? No one else has a car.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Down another 25% since no clarification yet.
Rounding down to the nearest percent...

Apparently GJO doesn't think that the question has been satisfied.  In the last week I've read about Faraday & Atieva revealing new cars at the car show in early January, but nothing was said about taking orders for them.
Has anybody heard anything about what if anything this question means?

Going back to consensus, because GJO will need to determine when NextEV sent the invitations out in order to resolve this question. If resolved, the question will be resolved on that date. Forecasts since then won't count. If not resolved, we continue as if nothing happened. If voided, none of it matters.

I'm not confident in a resolution. NextEV sent out a limited number of invitations to pre-order its forthcoming hypercar. Apparently, the small number of cars on offer were all pre-sold. But we don't know when, and this question opened on 17 May. So some possibilities:

Filed for resolution, based on the seeking alpha news item:
http://seekingalpha.com/article/4012053-nextev-atieva-faraday-future-finalize-development-tesla-competitors

been thinking more about the NextEV "invitation only" EV car sale.  You can't just open up the doors and let anyone order one of the 10 or 20 coveted EV cars slotted to be built.  What would happen to NextEVs reputation if Donald Trump bought one?  I bet only beautiful famous people have been asked to drive one around.

Are we seeing a shift in the car industry?  Is this a change in American Culture?  The EV industry seems to be modeled after the U.S. Department of Defense Acquisitions Program....That is fork over huge amounts of money and buy something that has not made it off paper.  Oh my.

http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20161013006663/en/NextEV-Officially-Opens-North-American-Headquarters
According to this story, they have been issued a permit to begin testing.  A wise company would not take orders for a vehicle that has not been thoroughly tested, I wouldn't think.

Considering the apparently wide range of plausible interpretations of this question, as evidenced by almost all of the comments so far, this might be a good candidate for withdrawal, or at least very detailed explanation.
Up 25% until there is some clarification. Reminds me of the canal questions (some of which were voided).

Has NextEV already took orders and sold their first batch of cars?  Were the cars sold prior to this question being initiated?  Not sure what to do here? Thanks to @morrel and @praedico for discussing it.  going to 4% (consensus) until something is resolved or clarified.

How can you sell something without taking orders first?
I'm wondering how GJO defines "high-end":  by price?  Atieva's car is certainly "high end" in my book if price is the criteria!   by functionality/features?  
And how GJO defines "challenge"?  All the articles I have read include analysis of how Atieva's ev (and others in development) challenge Tesla, and conclude the challenge is  significant.

Seems pretty clear.
"Graphs and Stats" shows the Q opened on May 17th, 2016.
It is possible that this question was, through inadvertence, not worded optimally.  I suppose therefore that either the Mack people or the GJO staff intend to clarify at the earliest opportunity.

There it is.  To be introduced Nov. 21 in London.
Where can Elon buy one?

Up 10%. How many wouldn't mind being the "Chinese Musk?" Very low bar to take an order (from Elon or a relative or someone in a bank who gave them money).

up 30 more% on @Khalid comment and @Raisinville at 100%.  I'm just skeptical of Chinese business in the U.S. coupled with a startup is all.  Seems to have the making of a disaster....random thought time...If China could build confidence with Americans in the U.S. by delivering and by displaying integrity with China business internal reporting....life could be good for everyone.

I took a closer look at @Kate 's link and the GJ question.  The Chinese New year falls on 28 Jan 2017 on the US calendar.  The link says "NextEV electric supercar to be unveiled in 2016 and sold in a small number".  If you watch the video she says that the car will be introduced in China only.  The GJ question says "in 2016" I take that to mean a US calendar versus a Chinese calendar?  From a Chinese perspective the car could be released 20 Jan 2017 in China 20 days after this question closed yet still be considered 2016 in China....hmmmm.  Maybe I'm reading too much into it?  Considering 1-7 Oct 2016 is National Day and nobody is working in China this week I'll go a couple points above consensus until I can make more sense of it all.  Anyone want to help me out?
Going up slightly on news that NextEV intends to unveil its hypercar in November. Still no photos of the actual car, though.
@Raisinville's link re NextEV, but hedge on "shortly"

I have started taking orders for my electric vehicles.  I have no plans to produce or deliver any, but order along if you want to.  If were one of the listed companies, since it is 2016 and I am taking orders, this Q would have to be resolved as Yes.  Am I the only one bothered by this?
Not until there are sufficient test vehicles on the road to prove that they can reliably manufacture production vehicles.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

As far as I can tell, this question remains meaningless.  I can "take orders" for anything any time I want to, even if delivery is scheduled for 2106.  Hoping for a modicum of reality in all of this, I am staying low.  I don't think they'll be ready to deliver anything in any future near enough to justify "taking orders" in 2016.

Less likely with lower gasoline prices.
Down 3% thanks to update from @JamieDeith below.

All 3 companies are making news. Update:
NextEV: Plans to unveil an electric hypercar by end of 2016. If you have to ask the price it's not for you. With billionaire backing, pre-orders seem very unlikely: <1%
Atieva: Has a souped up Mercedes van 900hp (!!), and 2018 mentioned for a sedan: downgrading to <<1%
Faraday Future: Just hired a big GM name for "Lead engineering operations for powertrain, battery and related high voltage systems". Sounds serious enough, but it is hard to see any pre-orders this soon in the design phase: <<1%
Passage of time and the fact that consensus is at 5% make it even less likely.
NextEV is talking about doing something by year-end, at least a prototype or a demo or something. May or may not equate to "taking orders"; stay tuned.

From: http://www.autocar.co.uk/car-news/new-cars/new-£1m-nextev-electric-hypercar-track-2016-reveal
"NextEV, the Chinese-backed electric vehicle start-up headed by former president of Ford of Europe Martin Leach, is on track to reveal its first car, a battery-powered hypercar, “somewhere in Europe” before the end of the year."

Every time I encounter this question it irritates me more.  I can take orders any time, for anything, for delivery at any time.  If I were a fraudulent alternative automobile firm, I would start taking orders like nobody's business to jack up my investors' confidence.  But the orders really would represent "nobody's business."  In a long and proud line of ill-conceived Qs, this one is very close to the worst. Congratulations.
Dropping 5% to be closer to the consensus.
It's only taking orders. Also there's 3 different companies and it's phrased as "or".

Pokemon Go player discovers a Tesla at NextEv's San Jose, CA HQ.
http://electrek.co/2016/07/14/nextev-benchmarking-tesla-model-x/
Slow economic growth and continuing low oil prices make this less likely.

NextEv, not Faraday Future, may be the best candidate for a 2016 sale.  Sub header on this article indicates sales may start in 2016, although the article, seems to go no further than indicating NextEv may have a "Supercar" EV to display by the end of 2016.
http://www.autoblog.com/2016/07/06/nextev-chief-martin-leach-praises-tesla-motors-sort-of/

I'm going to put the odds higher than consensus for these reasons: The question is about taking orders for EVs and must be evaluated with scope sensitivity through the end of the year and sum up the independent probabilities of any of these companies accepting an order for a vehicle. Perhaps NextEV is aiming to be a supplier in the near term but they might take orders for race cars that are non-consumer, all they need is an order or two behind the scenes to a collector perhaps... 3%, if that counts. Could Atieva who has a prototype, accept orders for non-production prototypes already built like the one at the Beijing auto show? That might not fit the definition of the question... but it's an idea.. 2%. Also... TSLA is accepting orders for cars to be produced in 2018 and Atieva has promised to be producing in 2018. After the auto show they might start preorders, who knows? 25%. http://www.digitaltrends.com/cars/atieva-ev-news-rumors-specs-sketch/
They have a TSLA exec and he could want to follow this trend to help raise cash. Taking orders does not have to be consumer orders. Could be a protype. Faraday looks newer but has a concept race car they could sell, thereby "accepting" orders technically. 3%. All told that is 33% probability if all are independent possibilities.
Conflicting reports on whether NextEV will have a display model by end of the year. One article says "might"...

Review; I went back and reviewed again the open vacancies  at the three start-ups.  No new news still have tons of positions open including finance, sales, and marketing.  So I am maintaining no on the this question and moving down to 1% from 5%.

"Faraday is one of several Chinese-funded startups hoping to challenge Tesla Motors"  I know of another Chinese startup right down the road from the proposed FF plant going in Vallejo California. They are called Icon Aircraft, "Icon received... $60 million cash infusion... led by a top-notch privately held strategic investor from China"  Icon just let go all 160 plant workers it hired within the last six months and it does not look good for Icon.  All I'm saying is be careful... the Chinese way of business is a lot like "economic hitmen" the way John Perkins has described in his books.

Faraday Future (seems like the best shot at 2016 sales) gains permit to test self driving cars.  Reportedly to start mfg and sales in 2017.
http://www.businessinsider.com/faraday-future-to-test-self-driving-electric-cars-in-california-2016-6
Down another 5% to be closer to consensus. Some of the three companies seem borderline vapor (hard) ware. Still the bar for a yes might be very low.

NextEV seems focused heavily on a racecar, can't find any hint of consumer models: <<5%
Atieva: atieva.com talks about premium cars for the 2020's: <<5%
Faraday Future: http://www.ff.com/futuresight/mule-testing/ as of April 2016 has an opening - "Matt encourages anyone seeking to “engage and innovate in the industry” to seek out and apply for one of our available chassis and powertrain engineering positions." Sounds like 2016 orders are a very long shot: <<5%
Down 10% to be closer to consensus.

You know timing is everything...I hope these EV folks time the plant completion and rollout of their car at the end of the next recession versus during.  Plus I don't even think taking reservations for these cars would be a good idea secondary to the recession coming...people will be raising money not spending.  Taking reservations could be a risk.  I would use the recession to my advantage and take time hiring great talent at the same time tech starts lay offs in the bay area.

Taking orders sets the bar very low. Yet these companies seem more hype - smoke and mirrors - than production-ready. 
2016 still sounds too soon.

Taking those companies in order: Faraday Future 0%. With no vehicle, it is unlikely to get orders.

It takes time to create a car and to install the production capabilities.

1. How many businesses in general fail within two years? 
2. However, there is a difference between "failure" and "no orders" (i.e. "total failure")
3. Additionally, we are tracking demand for the cars, not sales themselves; therefore, what is the current state of demand in the market for passenger vehicles?
4. What is the state of demand for electric vehicles?
5. Does demand perfectly correlate with a company's ability to start taking orders (would the companies have started taking orders even if there had been no demand)?

(down 1% so I can re-post immediately) Second part of an informal poll (partly since I can't remember what the drift of the comments have been, belated kudos to @Flyn1200 for first raising this issue).
(no change) First of two parts of an informal poll (partly since I can't remember what the drift of the comments have been, belated kudos to @Flyn1200 for first raising this issue).
They seem to be in the early stages of promoting mission statements, hiring, and breaking ground for factories.  It seems premature for starting to take orders for vehicles in 2016.

Take orders yes, but on the delivery side they will fall short. I am not too bullish on the way the Chinese do business and Faraday is more hype than reality and to make it reality there are more things in the "shady" side of the tree than out there in the open. To prolong the appearance of legitimacy, they will have to take in order this year.
Law suits over oil production methods will start to erode the viability of BIG OIL stocks and MONEY will run to anyone with a plan to rent sunlight.

A lot of Chinese money flying around -to what purpose it's not clear. Faraday Future gives no indication that it will be producing a car in the near future. Neither does Atieva. NextEV's factory will open this year, but the only car it mentions for this year is a super-expensive supercar:
These are young companies. It took Tesla a few years to get off the ground.
Taking orders and delivering them are different!
Starting close with consensus, not sure when orders book will open and don't have enough knowledge to make an informed decision
The number is only this high given the ambiguity of "taking orders": What if a company opens a list but no one wants a car? What if the cars are ordered without a price being set?

The main riddle here is whether any of these companies will go with some sales model similar to Tesla's Model 3, taking orders far in advance of car availability.  I don't see any of these companies selling a car this year - Faraday indicates that it will be in two years, Atieva has openings for 49 people at its website, and not low-level positions either.  At this point, their website looks like they're recruiting staff rather than selling a car (IMHO).  NextEV hopes to start production this year - but they sound like a component manufacturer.  References are to a plant manufacturing motors and electronics modules - not sure where the electric vehicle with super car performance comes from but it would need to be built somewhere too.  And again, a website that looks focused on recruiting & VC.

FF does not have sales folks hired, NextEV does not have a Senior Accountants, Atieva does not have marketing folks.   first things first...you gotta have people to take sales orders.  All three companies don't have many... many positions filled yet.  I'm reluctant to answer this question because in my mind an order for an EV means a sales contract versus a "reservation" for a spot to buy.  I bet all three companies will ask for reservations which will cost people a grand or two but there won't be an actual sales order because they won't know how much one will cost until they hire the people to design and build these things.  I'm going low for now.  Anybody got any add ons?
Tesla proved orders can lead production by years.

Faraday Future does not plan to ship until 2017, but even that seems suspect as they have not finished their plant. [http://www.wsj.com/articles/electric-car-maker-faraday-breaks-ground-in-nevada-1460589107]
